content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. A zoo has <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> young turtles of a certain species. The zookeeper is interested in the relationship between the age in months and the length in centimeters (<math alttext="centimeters" overflow="scroll"><mtext>cm</mtext></math>) of the <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> turtles. A scatterplot and the least-squares regression line relating age and length of the <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> turtles are shown. The least-squares regression equation is <math alttext="predicted length equals, 18.258 plus 0.861 times, open parenthesis, age, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mtext>predicted length</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>18.258</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0.861</mn><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>age</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, and <math alttext="r squared equals 0.701" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>0.701</mn></math>. (a) Calculate and interpret the correlation coefficient, <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math>, between turtle age and length.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. A zoo has <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> young turtles of a certain species. The zookeeper is interested in the relationship between the age in months and the length in centimeters (<math alttext="centimeters" overflow="scroll"><mtext>cm</mtext></math>) of the <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> turtles. A scatterplot and the least-squares regression line relating age and length of the <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> turtles are shown. The least-squares regression equation is <math alttext="predicted length equals, 18.258 plus 0.861 times, open parenthesis, age, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mtext>predicted length</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>18.258</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0.861</mn><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>age</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, and <math alttext="r squared equals 0.701" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>0.701</mn></math>. (a) Calculate and interpret the correlation coefficient, <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math>, between turtle age and length.

(b) There are <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> turtles that are <math alttext="28" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>28</mn></math> months old. One is female and one is male. The female turtle has a residual of <math alttext="negative 2.27 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>2.27</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>cm</mtext></math>, and the male turtle has a residual of <math alttext="3.13 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.13</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>cm</mtext></math>.(i) On the scatterplot, circle the point that corresponds to the <math alttext="28" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>28</mn></math>-month-old female turtle.
(ii) Interpret the residual for the <math alttext="28" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>28</mn></math>-month-old male turtle in context.

The <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> turtles make up the zooâ€™s population for this species of turtle. There are <math alttext="8" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn></math> male turtles and <math alttext="12" overflow="scroll"><mn>12</mn></math> female turtles. The zookeeper wants to determine the strength of the relationship between sex of the turtle and length of the turtle. To do this, the zookeeper will use the point-biserial correlation. The point-biserial correlation is a measure of the strength of the relationship between a quantitative variable (e.g., length of the turtle) and a categorical variable with two categories (e.g., sex of the turtle). The value of the point-biserial correlation is between <math alttext="negative 1" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and like the correlation coefficient, values closer to <math alttext="negative 1" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></math> or <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> indicate a stronger correlation between the two variables. A formula for the point-biserial correlation is <math alttext="r sub p b equals, the fraction with numerator open parenthesis, m sub 1 minus m sub 2, close parenthesis times, the square root of p times, open parenthesis, 1 minus p, close parenthesis, end square root and denominator S D" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>r</mi> <mrow> <mi>p</mi> <mi>b</mi> </mrow> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <mfenced> <mrow> <msub> <mi>m</mi> <mn>1</mn> </msub> <mo>-</mo> <msub> <mi>m</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </mrow> </mfenced> <msqrt> <mi>p</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mn>1</mn> <mo>-</mo> <mi>p</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </msqrt> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>S</mi> <mi>D</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo>.</mo> </math> In this context, <math alttext="m sub 1 equals" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>m</mi> <mn>1</mn> </msub> <mo>=</mo> </math> the mean length of the male turtles, <math alttext="m sub 2 equals" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo></math> the mean length of the female turtles, <math alttext="p equals" overflow="scroll"><mi>p</mi><mo>=</mo></math> the proportion of the <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> turtles that are male, <math alttext="1 minus p equals" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>p</mi><mo>=</mo></math> the proportion of the <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> turtles that are female, and <math alttext="S D equals" overflow="scroll"> <mi>S</mi> <mi>D</mi> <mo>=</mo> </math> the standard deviation of the lengths of the <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> turtles. Numerical summaries for the <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"> <mn>20</mn> </math> turtle lengths are given in the following table. (c) Consider the strength of the relationship between sex and length. (i) Calculate the point-biserial correlation, <math alttext="r sub p b" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>r</mi> <mrow> <mi>p</mi> <mi>b</mi> </mrow> </msub> </math>, between length and sex of these <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> turtles.

(ii) The zoo also has a population of <math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>40</mn></math> tortoises, of which <math alttext="16" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>16</mn></math> are male and <math alttext="24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>24</mn></math> are female. The lengths of male and female tortoises tend to be more similar than the lengths of male and female turtles, but the overall variability in the lengths of tortoises is similar to that of the turtles. Based on the point-biserial correlations, would the strength of the relationship between length and sex for the tortoises be weaker or stronger than that of the turtles? Justify your answer.

Consider the original scatterplot of length versus age with the points identified by the sex of the turtle and summaries of the relationship between sex and age of the <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> turtles.MaleFemaleMean age (months)<math alttext="27" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>27</mn></math><math alttext="22" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>22</mn></math>Number of turtles<math alttext="8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn></math><math alttext="12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>12</mn></math>Standard deviation of age of the <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> turtles (months)<math alttext="4.86" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.86</mn></math>Point-biserial correlation between sex and age<math alttext="0.50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.50</mn></math>(d) Is age a confounding variable in the relationship between length and sex of the <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> turtles? Justify your answer based on the analysis conducted and the information provided.

topic.text: 2.4: Representing the Relationship Between Two Quantitative Variables

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Describe an appropriate method for gathering and representing data.
